metadata.title: Heart Failure
anatomical location body part affected: Left and right atria of the heart, left and right ventricles of the heart, lungs, and pulmonary veins
description: Heart failure (HF) is a condition caused by inefficient relaxation (incomplete filling) or contraction (reduced ejection) of the myocardium, resulting in a reduced cardiac output, elevated intracardiac pressures, or both. The condition can be categorized into different types and severities, occurs during rest or stress, and can be acute or chronic(1) –Types of heart failure include: -heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) or diastolic heart failure -heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) or systolic heart failure -low-output -high-output -right-sided -left-sided

Heart failure is a multisystem complex syndrome because the heart cannot supply enough oxygenated blood to meet the metabolic needs of the body. This causes impairment of endocrine, hematological, musculoskeletal, renal, respiratory, and vascular systems, which influence morbidity and mortality (2)

ICD-10 codes.I11.0: hypertensive heart disease with (congestive) heart failure (ICD-10-CA in Canada uses I11 without further subdivision)
ICD-10 codes.I13.0: hypertensive heart and renal disease with (congestive) heart failure (ICD-10-CA in Canada uses I13 without further subdivision)
ICD-10 codes.I13.2: hypertensive heart and renal disease with both (congestive) heart failure and renal failure (ICD-10-CA  in Canada uses I13 without further subdivision) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. Medicare reimburses for cardiac rehabilitation to treat patients with stable chronic heart failure (3)
presentation signs and symptoms: Signs and symptoms of right-sided  heart failure include:  –ascites/jaundice/enlarged liver –jugular vein distention –nausea and vomiting/indigestion/anorexia –nocturia –peripheral edema –right ventricular heave

Signs and symptoms of left-sided  heart failure include: –pulmonary crackles/productive cough –orthopnea –paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea –dyspnea, especially on exertion –fatigue –chest pain –heart murmur –S3 and S4 heart sound –tachycardia –weakness/fatigue/confusion/restlessness –cool/pale lower extremities –diminished peripheral pulses

The New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification of HF is as follows:(1) –Class I (mild) – Unrestricted physical activity –Class II (mild) – Some self-imposed  restriction in physical activity because of increased need to rest but no distress when resting –Class III (moderate) – Significantly unable to perform normal activities and limits activity due to need for rest from dyspnea and fatigue –Class IV (severe) – Inability to perform physical activity free of discomfort and heart failure signs/symptoms persist at rest and increase with any level of activity Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: The examination should be terminated if the patient experiences any cardiac symptoms
A significant change in vital signs would indicate need for termination of the exam; the physician should be notified
If the patient is experiencing discomfort or difficulty with breathing with any movement, that particular activity and, possibly, the exam should be terminated and the physician should be notified
Exercise testing is contraindicated when systolic blood pressure is greater than 200 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure is greater than 110 mm Hg

causes pathogenesis: Heart failure can occur at any age. However, it typically occurs with advancing age and with additional comorbidities (1,2)–Comorbid conditions contributing to or exacerbating heart failure include:-coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction-diabetes and metabolic syndrome-heart infection, such as pericarditis or endocarditis-atrial fibrillation or other arrythmias-heart valve disease-hypertension-chronic alcoholism-thyroid disease
The condition varies by patient: it can be acute or chronic and have gradual or rapid onset and progression

Heart failure can result from many conditions affecting the heart and blood vessels, including ischemic heart disease,valvular heart disease, arrhythmias, and hypertension. It can cause reduced cardiac output and circulation of oxygenatedblood to organs and tissue. As a result, renal, hepatic, and gastrointestinal ischemia and failure can ensue

Compensatory processes help the heart to function optimally during early stages of heart failure. These mechanisms aremostly caused by low cardiac output activating the sympathetic nervous system and the renin-angiotensin-aldosteronesystem(5)–Sympathetic nervous system stimulation  raises heart rate, BP, and force of myocardial contraction. While these actionsinitially raise cardiac output, eventually they tax the heart and increase its myocardial oxygen demand. Over time, themyocardium thickens and the heart enlarges. In the presence of coronary artery disease, the rise in myocardial oxygendemand can lead to myocardial ischemia–Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone  system activation  causes further vasoconstriction and sodium and water retention,leading to a boost in blood volume. The increased blood volume increases ventricular filling and consequently cardiacoutput. However, over time, the extra blood volume can overwhelm the heart and worsen heart failure. In addition, themyocardium can thicken further and eventually dilate. The dilated myocardium can no longer contract effectively
risk factors ,: Nonadherence to lifestyle changes including diet and exercise
Nonadherence to medication regimen and fluid/sodium restrictions

overall contraindications precautions: Head of patient’s bed should be placed in high-Fowler’s  position during acute heart failure or exacerbation to elevate the torso in an upright position at a 60˚ to 90˚ angle for maximum chest expansion and breathability. Supine/flat-lying  positions should be avoided (7,8)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

A significant change in vital signs would indicate need for termination of the exam; the physician should be notified
If the patient is experiencing discomfort or difficulty with breathing with any movement, that particular activity and, possibly, the exam should be terminated and the physician should be notified
Exercise testing is contraindicated when systolic blood pressure is greater than 200 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure is greater than 110 mm Hg

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document date of diagnosis and classification (IIV). Document date of any cardiac events. Note hospital course and any complications

course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Does the patient feel they are effectively controlling his or her symptoms? (1,2,7) vasodilators morphine inotropic medication supplemental oxygen diuretics ACE (angiotensin-converting  enzyme) inhibitors ARB (angiotensin receptor blocker) inhibitors ARN (angiotensin receptor neprilysin) inhibitors aldosterone inhibitors ivabradine (type of calcium channel blocker) beta-blockers digoxin
diagnostic tests completed: Accurate diagnosis of heart failure is essential for effective disease management, ongoing surveillance, and optimal patient outcomes

Echocardiogram to determine ejection fraction and whether heart failure is caused by diastolic dysfunction or systolic dysfunction by visualizing heart size, shape, valves, pumping action, and blood flow
Transesophageal echocardiogram or transthoracic echocardiogram to evaluate for differential diagnoses, such as blood clots or heart/valve disease
Chest X-ray,  which may identify pleural effusion, pulmonary edema, or heart enlargement, such as enlarged left ventricle
These laboratory tests can be used to determine the cause of heart failure:(1,6,7)
CBC with differential to detect anemia including low RBCs, which increase work of heart and trigger cardiac compensatory mechanisms
B-type  natriuretic peptide (BNP), also called brain natriuretic peptide elevation
Troponin level to determine elevated levels, which can indicate acute or chronic heart failure with decompensation, heart muscle injury, or cell death

Serology to test for levels of electrolytes, glucose, serum urea nitrogen (BUN), and creatinine, which can detect electrolyte imbalance or disturbance in kidney function, which indicates and exacerbates heart failure
Liver function test to evaluate for toxin buildup in the liver, also called liver congestion, that can occur with heart failure
Urinalysis to detect elevated specific gravity and protein in the urine ›Additional diagnostic tests to help identify cause include:(1,7)

›12lead  ECG to detect abnormal cardiac waveforms caused by acute or chronic heart failure and other cardiovascular pathology ›heart catheterization to evaluate hemodynamic values, to biopsy heart tissue, and to perform coronary angiogram ›exercise stress test to determine exercise tolerance and patterns of ischemia during exercise
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies, including stress management techniques (e.g., yoga, meditation), acupuncture, dietary changes (e.g., addition of cranberries or watermelon for diuresis, elimination of salt), and supplement use (e.g., hawthorn, coenzyme Q10)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Note which activities increase symptoms. Please see Presentation/signs and symptoms , above, for the NYHA classification of HF
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., dyspnea at rest and/or with activity). Ask about feelings of chest pressure or tightness
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Where appropriate, use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale may be used to assess exercise intolerance
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Patients may experience increase in symptoms in cold or hot weather
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. How many pillows does the patient use? -Prevalence of sleep apnea in chronic HF has been reported to be 4582%(11) and may be associated with increased morbidity and mortality -Ask if patient has symptoms such as daytime sleepiness, restless or fitful sleep, insomnia, loud snoring, or choking or gasping during sleep -Patients with HF often experience nocturia
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Respiratory symptoms of HF, particularly shortness of breath, are nonspecific, and may also be due to underlying respiratory disease or physical deconditioning -Does the patient require the use of supplemental oxygen? If so, what are the parameters set by the physician? -Does the patient require the use of CPAP or other nighttime breathing assistance device secondary to sleep apnea? -Does patient complain of coughing or wheezing? -A dry, irritating cough can occur, particularly at night. Patients may have a history of being mistakenly treated for asthma or bronchitis Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe_________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Inquire about previous hospitalizations for HF and previous history of cardiac disease
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Clinical depression is a common comorbidity, affecting up to 40% of patients with chronic HF(12) Up to 75% of patients report elevated depressive symptoms(12) Coexisting COPD is common among patients with chronic HF Approximately 2030%  of patients with COPD have chronic HF(18) COPD in patients with HF was associated with older age, more comorbidities, reduced exercise capacity, and increased cardiovascular mortality/HF hospitalization in a study investigating clinical characteristics of patients with both conditions(19)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient employed? What does the job require? Does the patient participate in any recreational activities? Any hobbies?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document prior and current functional level as reported by patient and family
social and occupational history.living environment: Ask about stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home. Are any modifications necessary? Does the patient have sufficient endurance to negotiate stairs to enter home or access bedroom or bathroom?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: BMI; obesity is a risk factor for cardiac disease. Patients may be instructed to monitor their weight and body swelling daily to recognize signs of fluid retention. Rapid weight gain or increase in girth measurements are early signs of fluid buildup Document patient’s orientation to time, place, and situation. Is patient alert or lethargic? Onset of confusion, restlessness, dizziness, or lightheadedness may be symptoms of worsening HF, requiring medical attention –Use the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) to screen for cognitive impairment as indicated -Results of a study conducted in the Netherlands suggest that severe cognitive impairment is a frequent but often unrecognized symptom in older HF patients(20) -Patients with more severe HF are at increased risk for severe cognitive impairment, and this is associated with higher mortality
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess if equipment is needed; if patient has equipment, assess for proper fit and use
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance in sit and stand, statically and dynamically –Authors of a retrospective chart review in the United States that involved 75 subjects, 20 with COPD and 55 with HF, found that the vast majority of patients were at increased fall risk based on objective data collected during initial physical therapy evaluation for home health services(13) -Data analyzed included scores from the Dynamic Gait Index (DGI), Tinetti Performance-Oriented  Mobility Assessment scale,Berg Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, 2-minute  walk test (2MWT), and gait speed -Of the 75 subjects, 94.7% were classified as being at risk for falls -It is recommended that cardiopulmonary rehabilitation programs should not just address cardiopulmonary impairments, but should also perform balance assessments and consider the impact of balance deficits on patients’ functional mobility
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Monitor the following at rest, in sitting, in standing, with ADLs, during and after gait, and after a rest period -Blood pressure, heart sounds, heart rate, Borg rating of perceived exertion (RPE) -EKG for abnormal heart rhythm -O2 saturation values; should be > 95% at rest but may vary by individual
Functional capacity tests may include the 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) and 10-meter  incremental shuttle-walk test
Borg RPE increasing above 14/20 (moderate exertion) during physical activity may indicate worsening HF
Auscultate as indicated. Increase in pulmonary crackles may indicate worsening HF

Assess inspiratory muscle strength as indicated using an inspirometer or manometer. Dysfunction of skeletal respiratory muscles is common in HF(21) -In addition, cardiac autonomic control of heart rate is associated with inspiratory muscle weakness in chronic HF
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Screen for radial/dorsalis pedis pulsesAssess for appropriate lifting technique, appropriate breathing when lifting, and compliance with weight restrictions. Note use of energy-conservation techniques and dyspnea relief positionsAssess independence in transfers and functional mobility. Monitor and document EKG changes and vital signs before, during, and after ADLs. Use FIM if appropriate
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess need for assistive device. Document any shortness of breath, pallor, cyanosis, or diaphoresis during ambulation. Provide immediate rest if these should occur. Document vital signs during and immediately following ambulation. Also, document time required to recover to normal resting values. Assess gait safety using DGI. Assess ability to negotiate stairs if appropriate
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess gross strength in upper and lower extremities and trunk to identify weakness. Resisted manual muscle tests may need to be delayed depending on physician’s orders
observation inspection palpation includi: duration, from 1 (01/4  inch, disappears rapidly) to 4 (> 1 inch still present after 5 minutes)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Take note of any obvious malalignments in posture that may interfere with exercise program
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROM and flexibility at all major joints to identify any limitationsIdentify tasks patient may have difficulty with; determine if decreased endurance limits self-care  activities. Monitor and document EKG changes and vital signs before, during, and after ADLs
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Quality of life questionnaire (e.g., Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire) to assess patient’s perceived QOL, Borg RPE Scale to rate the intensity of exercise for the patient, and Dutch Heart Failure Knowledge Scale to assess how any education about the disease has affected the patient

contraindications precautions: Heart rate ≥100 bpm in supine at rest
Body mass increase of ≥ 4 lbs (1.8 kg) over the course of 1 to 3 days
Myocardial infarction in the last 3 weeks
Ischemia that is significant at low work rates
Further reduction in exercise tolerance or dyspnea at rest or upon exertion over the last few days
Regurgitant valvular heart disease necessitating surgery

Other absolute contraindications -Symptoms and signs of congestion, unstable HF or NYHA functional class IV -Exercise-training-induced: -Myocardial ischemia -Hypotension -Nonsustained or sustained ventricular tachycardia -Atrial fibrillation (until resolved) -Active inflammatory disease -Cerebrovascular or musculoskeletal disease preventing exercise testing or training -Severe obstructive lung disease leading to arterial oxygen desaturation -Thyroid dysfunction, hypo-  or hyperkalemia, hypovolemia
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
All patients should obtain their cardiologist’s clearance before participating in an exercise program(8)

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Patients should undergo cardiopulmonary exercise testing prior to initiating a therapeutic program(8)
Avoid Valsalva maneuver (encourage normal breathing pattern)

If the patient is participating in aquatic therapy, he or she should remain in an upright position and submerge body no deeper than the xiphoid process. Obtain physician’s clearance for aquatic therapy and recommendations regarding water temperature and time spent in pool. Patient should be closely monitored for cardiac symptoms and changes in vital signs(14)

Contraindications to aquatic therapy include early cardiac failure, unstable angina, vital capacity < 1L, severe peripheral vascular disease, severe kidney disease, open wounds, urinary or fecal incontinence, infections, and uncontrolled seizure(15)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with HF generally present with impaired strength, cardiovascular endurance, functional mobility, and lack of knowledge about HF. Physical therapy can improve strength, cardiovascular endurance, functional mobility, and patient knowledge regarding HF. There can also be a benefit to the patient’s QOL, muscle structure, and physiological response to exercise.(16) An exercise program may also decrease future cardiac events and mortality(7)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Myocardial ischemia(9) Other common causes of dyspnea(9) –Asthma –COPD –Arrhythmia –Infection –Interstitial lung disease –Anemia –Pulmonary embolism (PE) –Sleep-disordered  breathing Other causes of peripheral edema(9) –DVT –Renal disease -Acute renal failure -Chronic kidney disease –Hepatic disease –Hypoproteinemia –Venous insufficiency –Immobility –Pregnancy –Endocrine disease –Drugs –Lymphedema Depression Anxiety and hyperventilation syndromes Deconditioning
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Social services for equipment, home needs Smoking cessation program, if necessary Nutritionist for fluid-,  calorie-,  fat-, and sodium-restricted diet Mental health professional if there are psychological issues (e.g., depression) Sleep specialist if sleep apnea is suspected
other considerations: Transitional care interventions (TCIs) have been developed to address the problem of numerous hospital readmissions and emergency department visits that occur with CHF(23) –Frequent use of healthcare services has been attributed to lack of understanding of a treatment plan, nonadherence to medical therapy, unawareness of HF symptom exacerbation, and irregular follow-up(23) –TCIs include a broad range of health services such as patient or caregiver education on self-management,  discharge planning, structured follow-up,  and coordination among healthcare professionals –Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  of RCTs investigating the impact of TCIs on acute health service use by patients with HF found that high-intensity  TCIs (combining home visits with telephone follow-up,  clinic visits, or both) reduced readmission risks regardless of the duration of follow-up.  Moderate-intensity  TCIs were effective if implemented for a longer duration (at least 6 months). Low-intensity  TCIs that involved only follow-up  in outpatient clinics or telephone follow-up  were not efficacious(23) -Forty-one  RCTs were included in the review and meta-analysis
treatment summary: Rehabilitation following HF diagnosis or exacerbation can include cardiac rehabilitation, physical therapy, and/or occupational therapy(10)  -Cardiac rehabilitation  is an interprofessional program that provides physiological and psychological counseling, education, and physical activities that reduce cardiac mortality. The programs are generally divided into 3 phases: -Phase I: For inpatient that ends about 4 weeks after hospitalization and includes activities such as breathing exercises with peak flow spirometry and walking exercises -Phase II: Early outpatient period that includes physical exercise and respiratory exercise that improves exercise capacity and positively impacts QOL -Phase III: Long-term  outpatient that in addition to the physical activities also includes education, counseling, and mindfulness program ›Physical therapy  should begin as soon as it is safe to and continue with an individualized and focused program with periodic progress evaluations. Activity can be challenging for patients with HF depending on severity of signs/symptoms but it is essential to promote recovery and maximal ability.Ongoing rehabilitation aims to restore strength and gait stability in ambulation after decompensation or reduced mobility during hospitalization for stabilization
Early ambulation is recommended as soon as patient’s cardiopulmonary condition is stable and optimal breathability is restored

Gait rehabilitation may involve exercises to improve muscle strength, coordination, and lung capacity ›Occupational therapy  teaches patients with debilitating signs/symptoms how to conserve energy, group tasks and locations together, and become more independent as tolerated. Patients deconditioned after hospitalization can learn how to perform ADLs and self-care  using modified strategies and techniques depending on severity of symptoms, such as cooking and washing dishes for a few minutes at a time while sitting on a stool/chair in kitchen instead of standing
Exercise-based  rehabilitation does not appear to increase risk of mortality and may reduce HF-related  hospitalizations in adults with systolic HF(10)

Authors of a single-blind  RCT conducted in Brazil concluded that the combination of a noninvasive ventilator system and aerobic and resistance training activities provides additional benefits for dyspnea and improves overall QOL in patients with moderate heart failure(25) –Forty-six  patients with a diagnosis of moderate HF were randomized to a 10-week  program of aerobic and resistance training combined with noninvasive ventilator support (n = 23) or aerobic and resistance training only (n = 23) –Patients were tested using the 6MWT and assessed using the forced vital capacity, forced expiratory volume at one second (FEV1), maximal inspiratory muscle pressure, maximal expiratory muscle pressure, London Chest Activity of Daily Living Scale, and the Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire –After 10 weeks those in the noninvasive ventilator support group had significant improvements on the London Chest Activity of Daily Living Scale and the Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire

Authors of a 2017 systematic review and meta-analysis  conducted in Australia have suggested that moderate and vigorous aerobic exercise training can improve flow-mediated  dilation in patients with HF(26) . increased patient knowledge regarding ca: The Dutch Heart Failure Knowledge Scale to assess how any education about the disease has affected the patient
improved cardiopulmonary endurance and f: Borg RPE Scale to rate the intensity of exercise
improved balance: Balance measures such as Berg Balance Scale
improved quality of life: Quality of life questionnaires(17)–Generic-Nottingham Health Profile-Sickness Impact Profile-Short Form Health Survey (SF-36)–Disease specific-Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire-Quality of Life in Severe Heart Failure Questionnaire-Chronic Heart Failure Questionnaire
improved sleep efficiency: Number of apneic events, number of nocturnal arousals

maintenance or prevention: Patients should continue with a cardiac rehabilitation program under medical supervision until it is appropriate to continue independently at home, with written instructions and education provided to patient and family. The maintenance phase will typically begin after 6 months of supervised training(4,22)

Patients should be instructed to watch for signs of overexertion such as shortness of breath that prevents completing a sentence; shortness of breath that does not get better when activity is decreased; dizziness or lightheadedness; chest pain or tightness; pain in arms, shoulders, neck, or jaw; irregular pulse; extreme fatigue; severe sweating; and nausea or vomiting If any of these symptoms develops during activity, patient should slow down. If symptoms do not subside, activity should be stopped Call 911 if chest pain or other symptoms are not relieved Patients and caregivers should monitor for signs of worsening HF such as shortness of breath, weight gain, and increase in swelling

The 2016 European Guidelines on cardiovascular disease prevention in clinical practice include the following recommendations for achieving medication and lifestyle adherence:(24) Simplifying the treatment regimen to the lowest acceptable level is recommended, with repetitive monitoring and feedback. In the case of persistent nonadherence, multi-session  or combined behavioral interventions are recommended It is recommended that health personnel and caregivers set an example by following healthy lifestyles, such as not smoking at work
